High acidic vegetable oil feedstocks and wastes are not suitable for conventional biodiesel production. These wastes could be used to produce cheap hydrocarbon-rich biofuels without affecting food production. In this work, we studied the hydrogen-free fast pyrolysis and deoxygenation of an acidic industrial vegetable oil waste for biofuels and chemicals production, assessing the effect of Ce or Zr on NiAl mixed oxides obtained from layered double hydroxides. Oily waste (OW) was pre-adsorbed on the catalysts using a Catalyst:OW mass ratio of 5:1. Without a catalyst, pyrolysis of OW, containing triglycerides and a high percentage of free fatty acids, produced mainly 1-alkenes, lower carbon chain fatty acids, and fatty acid esters. Catalytic pyrolysis increased hydrocarbons favoring 1-alkenes between propene and 1-heptadecene, as well as alkyl-benzenes. Linear alkylbenzenes are feedstock for the production of biodegradable surfactants. NiAlCe was most selective to polyenes, alkanes and ketones, while NiAl and NiAlZr catalysts were efficient in producing aromatics, alkenes and light hydrocarbons in the GLP and gasoline range (C3-C10). The combination of acidic and metallic properties on high surface area unsupported bulk mixed oxide catalysts can be used to maximize the production of specific-range hydrocarbons for second-generation drop-in biofuels and bio-based surfactant precursors, towards the decarbonization of industry. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cracking Oil residue Layered double hydroxides Pyrolysis Unsupported catalysts Abbreviations FFA free fatty acid HDO hydrodeoxygenation LDH layered double hydroxide OW oily waste PC principal component PCA principal component analysis S.A surface area TA terephthalate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The use of fossil fuels as energy sources leads to a number of consequences, including the emission of a wide variety of air pollutants, such as carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxides, sulfur oxides, carbon monoxide and particulates, contributing to increasing extreme climate events [1]. The UN report on climate change of August 2021 stated the imperative need to reach net-zero carbon emissions to mitigate the negative effects of the excessive greenhouse effect by promoting the use of cleaner renewable energy sources [2]. Biodiesel and ethanol are two renewable sources of energy produced on a large scale, but they use raw materials such as soybean and sugarcane that compete directly with food purposes [3,4]. The industrial production of edible soybean and other vegetable oils usually generates hundreds of tons a year of triglyceride residues containing high content of free fatty acids [5]. However, high acidic fatty compounds are not proper for the conventional biodiesel process because they could form a high amount of soaps [6]. In this case, heterogeneous catalysts can be used to avoid the production of undesirable compounds during biodiesel production [7,8]. Among various types of biomasses used to obtain bio-oil rich in hydrocarbons, vegetable oil-derived triglycerides are extensively recognized as excellent raw materials. To be used as a drop-in conventional fuel, fatty compounds require total deoxygenation [9]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) using precious or transition metal catalysts can be used to produce hydrocarbons in the jet fuel and diesel range. But this process consumes a large amount of hydrogen with excessive cost [10]. Hydrogen-free catalytic cracking and pyrolysis are alternative ways to produce hydrocarbons [11]. Pyrolysis consists of promoting the thermal degradation of potential feeds at a temperature between 400 and 700 °C under an inert atmosphere [12]. Pyrolysis of different types of fatty wastes has been reported, such as fat, oils and grease [13], vegetable oil refining by-product [14], used frying oil [15,16] and soybean oil soapstock [17]. However, the bio-oil obtained from the thermal pyrolysis of biomass has a high content of oxygenated compounds leading to low stability and limited calorific value of the bio-oil [18]. An alternative is the use of catalytic conversion to obtain hydrocarbon-rich products [19,20]. Acid and metallic catalysts have been widely developed and applied in deoxygenation, hydrodeoxygenation and pyrolysis reactions using triglycerides, fatty acid esters and fatty acids as model compounds of vegetable oil and oily waste for a better understanding of reaction mechanisms and to improve hydrocarbon selectivity [19]. In previous works, we have reported the pyrolysis and deoxygenation of fatty compounds using catalysts with different acidities, such as Al2O3, SiO2, [21]. The use of alumina in oleic acid pyrolysis favored the production of hydrocarbons in the gasoline range, while palmitic acid pyrolysis favored hydrocarbons in both jet fuel and gasoline range [22]. The combination of metal sites with an acidic site can favor selectivity to deoxygenated products and simultaneous cracking. The use of nickel supported on alumina, prepared by impregnation, increased deoxygenation in the pyrolysis of fatty acids, producing high content of alkene isomers and aromatics [23,24]. However, nickel can be combined with alumina in the form of mixed oxides with a high specific area, coming from layered double hydroxides (LDH) [25]. The pyrolysis of myristic acid on mixed oxides NiAl produced from LDH showed modulated acidity that can favor the production of hydrocarbons in the range of gasoline or jet fuel, or even aromatics, depending on Ni/Al ratio [26]. However, Ni-based catalysts can suffer deactivation during pyrolysis by carbon deposition and metal sintering. To limit this problem, the design of composition and structure of bifunctional catalysts has been studied, considering the type of support, interaction metal-support and nanosize particles [27]. The use of zirconium as a catalyst promoter can change the interaction between metals and reactants. Masuda et al. [28] have studied the influence of ZrO2/FeOOH on the conversion of palm oil, showing an oxygen transfer from H2O that increased the activity and selectivity to hydrocarbons and butanones. This result was justified because ZrO2 has the ability to generate active hydrogen and oxygen species from H2O. Arias et al. [25] observed that the introduction of zirconium in NiAlOx mixed oxide catalysts, prepared from layered double hydroxides, caused a reduction in the acidity of the NiAlOx oxides, reducing the interaction of Ni and Al and favoring the dehydrogenation of cyclohexane. Another interesting promoter of Ni-based catalysts is cerium, which can significantly enhance catalyst efficiencies. During biomass pyrolysis, Pang et al. [29] observed that the Ce4+ of the CeO2 oxide supported on the Al2O3 surface was reduced to Ce3+ in a reducing atmosphere and high temperature, removing oxygen atoms to form oxygen vacancies, thus increasing the redox performance of the catalyst. At the same time, biomass pyrolysis produced H2O through dehydration and deoxygenation reactions, increasing the interaction with cerium species and favoring the degree of deoxygenation of the products. Amaya et al. [30] studied the influence of vermiculite with acidity modulated by Al-Zr or Al-Ce on the performance of Ni and NiMo for the hydroconversion of decane. Fu et al. [31], studied the role of ceria in Ni/CeO-Al2O3 catalysts in the deoxygenation of bio-lipids. The authors observed that the oxygen vacancies formed by cerium doping on Al2O3 support weakened the strong Ni-Al interaction, favoring the dispersion of nickel sites. The addition of cerium to the NiCeAl catalyst also increased the weak and medium acidity and decreased the strong acidity, limiting the cleavage of the C-C single bond of hydrocarbons and therefore the coke formation. Another important effect due to cerium addition is the increase in the dispersion of Ni particles in the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, which increases the activity and reduces deactivation [32]. The studies of NiZrAl and NiCeAl catalysts have usually been carried out in a Ni-supported system prepared by impregnation on Al2O3, CeO2 and ZrO2. Studies on unsupported catalyst systems based on mixed oxides obtained from layered double hydroxides are rare. Therefore, this article aims to evaluate the effect of Ce and Zr on NiAl mixed oxides obtained from layered double hydroxides in a hydrogen-free pyrolysis and deoxygenation of industrial vegetable oil waste to produce second-generation biofuels and petrochemicals. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of materials The precursor materials, NiAl-LDH, NiAlCe-LDH and NiAlZr-LDH, were prepared by the coprecipitation method as previously described [25]. Essentially, two solutions (100 mL each) at pH 6.5 ± 0.3 were added dropwise simultaneously into a round-bottom flask containing 100 mL of deionized water previously boiled at 105 °C to remove dissolved CO2 and avoid carbonate formation during LDH synthesis. The addition of solutions was performed slowly under agitation at 55 °C over 45 min. One of the solutions contained the metallic sources (0.5 mol L−1): aluminum nitrate, Al(NO3)3.9H2O (Dinâmica, 98.5%) and nickel nitrate, Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%) for NiAl-LDH. In addition to these salts, the following were added: ammonium cerium (IV) nitrate, (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 (Vetec, 99%), or zirconium (IV) oxychloride, ZrOCl2.8H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.5%), for NiAlCe-LDH and NiAlZr-LDH synthesis, respectively. The other solution contained sodium hydroxide (1.0 mol L−1), NaOH (Merck, 99%) and terephthalic acid (0.19 mol L−1), C8H6O4 (Aldrich, 98 %) as a source of terephthalate anion [TA2−]. All reagents were added in stoichiometric amounts according to LDH general formula Ni0.3(Al+M(IV))0.7(OH)2[TA2−]0.35.mH2O, with M(IV) = Ce(IV) or Zr(IV) and Al:M(IV) molar ratio 1:1. The only exception was the terephthalic acid that was added in an excess of 10 mol% more than the stoichiometric amounts, to favor its incorporation as the compensation anion in the layered double hydroxides. The precipitates were aged under stirring for 20 h with the first four hours at 55 °C and the remaining time at room temperature. The solid phases were recovered by vacuum filtration, washing with deionized boiled water until reaching neutral pH. Next, the materials were dried in an oven at 80 °C for 36 h. Mixed oxide catalysts NiAl, NiAlCe and NiAlZr were obtained after calcination of the precursor materials at 600 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under static air. The addition of oily waste (OW) to catalysts, that had been pre-dried at 110 °C, was achieved at room temperature by manual grinding in a ceramic crucible at a 5:1 catalyst:OW mass ratio. At the end of this process, the materials were always completely powdered. The mixtures were identified as OW/catalyst: OW/NiAl, OW/NiAlCe and OW/NiAlZr. 2.2 Pyrolysis experiments The pyrolysis feedstock was an acidic oily waste from a soybean vegetable oil processing industry located in Cabo de Santo Agostinho, Pernambuco State, Brazil. Fast pyrolyses of oily waste and oily waste adsorbed on catalysts, were conducted in a Frontier Tandem Rx-3050TR µ-reactor interfaced to a Shimadzu GC/MS QP2020 gas chromatograph. The sample mass amount was around 250 µg for OW and 1500 µg for the OW/catalyst, ensuring that the amount of material available for pyrolysis was always the same in all experiments [26]. The sample was first weighed in a steel cup; then quartz wool was added above the sample to avoid any loss of the solid during the descent of the cup within the pyrolysis set-up. The cup with the sample was dropped into the first reactor module preheated to 600 °C and was maintained at this temperature for 18 s; the pyrolysis vapors passed through an empty tube in the second reactor module that worked as an interface at 300 °C to prevent premature condensation of pyrolysis products evolved. Helium was used as the carrier gas to transfer the volatile products to CG/MS system. The products were analyzed with a SH-Rtx-5 column (60 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 µm); the thermal program used began at 45 °C for 5 min, followed by a heating ramp (5 °C min−1) up to 280 °C, maintaining this temperature for 10 min. The temperatures of the ion source and the injector were kept at 250 °C; the GC–MS interface was set at 290 °C. Mass spectrum was run in scan mode in the range of 40–400 m/z. Peak identification by GC/MS analysis was based on comparison with data from the NIST library and only compounds with a similarity higher than 85% were processed as identified ones. All the pyrolysis experiments were carried out in duplicate. 2.3 Characterization of materials and oily feedstock The elemental chemical composition of the samples was obtained by Energy Dispersive X-Ray Analysis (EDX) using a Rigaku NEX DE VS spectrometer, 10 mm analysis spot size, irradiation time for 100 s under a helium atmosphere. For these analyses, three K lines were used: Y-Gd at 60 kV tube voltage and 200 µA for cerium and zirconium detection, K-Sr at 35 kV and 47 µA for nickel measurement and Na-Cl K lines at 6.5 kV and 320 µA for aluminum quantification. X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained on a Rigaku diffractometer Smartlab SE model in the 3–70° 2θ range using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The analysis parameters were 40 kV voltage, 40 mA current, a step of 0.02° and a speed of 2° min−1. FTIR (Fourier Transform Infrared) spectra between 4000 and 850 cm−1 were obtained in a Bruker Tensor II spectrometer coupled with ATR module (Attenuated Total Reflectance); 30 scans were made for each sample and 30 scans for the background. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in a NETZSCH ST A449 F3 Jupiter instrument. About 10 mg of sample was placed in an alumina sample pan and heated from 25 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under 50 mL min−1 of synthetic air flow. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were taken at -196 °C in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. The surface area of the catalysts was calculated using the BET (Brunauer, Emmett, Teller) method. The BJH (Barret, Joyner and Halenda) method was utilized to calculate the pore size distribution and the total pore volume was calculated based on the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at P/P0 = 0.99. The amount and strength of the acid sites present in the oxides were estimated by pyridine desorption. 0.1 g of catalyst was placed in a tubular reactor and heated to 400 °C for 2 h under an argon atmosphere with a gas flow of 100 mL.min−1, for cleaning the surface of the materials. Then, the temperature was lowered to 95 °C and a stream of inert gas saturated with pyridine vapor was passed through the reactor over a period of 40 min. After this exposure time and still at the same temperature, a flow of pure argon was used for 40 min to remove the weakly or physically adsorbed pyridine. Finally, 20–30 mg of the samples containing the remaining pyridine were subjected to TGA analysis on heating up to 900 °C (heating rate = 10 °C.min−1) under a nitrogen flow rate of 50 mL.min−1 [21]. Every mass loss event due to pyridine desorption (i event) was used as a parameter to calculate the number of acid sites, using the following equations: (1) n p y r i d i n e = m p y r i d i n e M M p y r i d i n e (2) N i = n p y r i d i n e m c a t a l y s t (3) T o t a l a c i d i t y = ∑ N i Where npyridine, mpyridine and MMpyridine are respectively the number of mols, mass and molar mass of pyridine; mcatalyst is the catalyst mass; Ni is the acidity in mols of pyridine per gram of catalyst. The acidic sites were classified as weak and medium strength (30 °C–280 °C temperature range, Lewis acids), and strong strength (280 °C–620 °C temperature range, strong Lewis acid and Bronsted acid sites). The medium and strong acidic sites are related to chemisorbed pyridine. The quantification of the percentage of free fatty acids (FFA), that is the number of grams of fatty acid as oleic acid in 100 g of oily waste, was estimated according to the AOCS Ca 5a-40 method [33]: about 1.0 g of oily waste was placed in a flask containing 12.5 ml of ethanol and two drops of phenolphthalein as an indicator. The sample was titrated by drop-wise addition of a standard NaOH 0.25 mol L−1 solution. This procedure was performed in triplicate. 2.4 Principal component analysis (PCA) PCA is a technique widely used in pyrolysis studies, enabling the reduction of the dimensionality of correlated data, transforming them into another set of uncorrelated data, called principal components (PC) [34–36]. Each PC is obtained through the linear combination of the original data. In this study, a PCA was performed on the peak area data of the compounds from the thermal and catalytic pyrolysis of the oily waste, to analyze the correlations between the products obtained. 3 Results 3.1 Precursors and catalysts characterization Precursor materials EDX elemental analysis results are shown in Table 1 . It was assumed that during precursor calcination no metallic sublimation or lixiviation could happen: then the percentages of Ni, Al, Ce and Zr would be the same in both oxides and layered double hydroxide precursors. The 0.7 x theoretical molar ratios were not reached with precision (x = (Al+M(IV))/(Ni+Al+M(IV))); but the three different metallic compositions (NiAl, NiAlCe and NiAlZr) enabled a study of the effect of the metallic nature on the properties of the materials and on the pyrolysis of oily waste. The materials NiAlCe-LDH and NiAlZr-LDH presented higher x values than NiAl-LDH, so there was greater incorporation of trivalent Al3+ and tetravalent Ce4+ and Zr4+. In the case of NiAl-LDH, when presenting a smaller x value, a higher content of nickel was observed (see Table 1), due to the lower incorporation of Al3+ in the material, as a result of metal leaching. Additionally, the percentage of nickel decreased with the addition of higher atomic mass metals Ce4+ and Zr4+. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of precursor materials NiAl-LDH, NiAlCe-LDH and NiAlZr-LDH are displayed in Fig. 1 . The diffraction reflections close to 2θ = 6.4°, 12.7°, 19.0°, 25.6° and 63.0° and their relative intensities are typical of layered double hydroxides [37]. No available standard patterns were found for LDH-terephthalate: then the Miller indexes were assigned to the main reflections in the diffractograms, as has been reported in previous studies [25]. For LDHs, the intense and regularly spaced basal reflections [00l] at low 2θ values correspond to successive orders of basal spacing c’. The basal spacing can be calculated from the (003) interplanar distance by Bragg´s Law with the value corresponding to the thickness of one layer plus the interlayer space. For all the materials, the d(003) distances are close to 13.9 Å (Table 1), similar to values reported for LDH-terephthalate intercalated with high water content. The layer thickness in LDH was 4.8 Å, the interlayer spacing was 9.1 Å, which is close to the size of the terephthalate anion in the vertical orientation with respect to the layers that is 9 Å [38]. Terephtalate provides a larger interlayer space when compared with common anions frequently used such as carbonate, hydroxide, chloride or nitrate. This minimizes the electrostatic repulsion between adjacent layers, stabilizes the LDH structure and allows the inclusion of a higher ratio of (III) and (IV) cations in the layers (high x values in the general formula of LDH) [10,25]. Table 1 shows the calculated “full width at half maximum” (°2θ) (FWHM) for the (003) XRD reflection, to have a measurement of the degree of crystallinity. The smaller FWHM value the more crystalline is the material. The NiAl-LDH presented the smallest FWHM value (see Table 1), indicating that this material was the most crystalline. The incorporation of Ce(IV) and Zr(IV) on the layer structure increased the FWHM values, indicating that a decrease in the crystallinity for NiAlCe-LDH and NiAlZr-LDH precursors, probably due to the introduction of significant distortions in the layers as a result of the substitution of Al (III) (ion radius 0.53 Å) by larger cations: Ce(IV) (ion radius 0.87 Å) and Zr(IV) (ion radius 0.72 Å) [39]. The material containing cerium presented the highest FWHM value, indicating that the distortion was more visible due to its higher cation size compared to Zr4+. An additional reason for NiAlCe-LDH being the least crystalline precursor is the presence of one additional phase to the LDH identified by the small diffraction peaks at 2θ = 8.7° and 14° (see asterisks in Fig. 1). These reflections have already been observed under similar synthesis conditions with high cerium contents, there being a limiting amount of Ce (IV) that can be incorporated into the layered structure of the LDH [10]. Additional evidence that suggests the incorporation of cerium and zirconium in the LDH layer structure are provided by the shift of the reflection (110) towards smaller angle values (see black arrow in Fig. 1). The reflection around 2θ = 62° corresponds to the crystallographic (110) plane, which is influenced by the layer compositions and the cationic radius. This reflection is independent of the layer stacking sequence and defines the lattice parameter a which can be calculated according to the formula a = 2 d(110). The lattice parameter a corresponds to the cation-cation distance in the brucite-like layers [37]. The a values calculated were 2.94, 2.98 and 2.99 Å for NiAl-LDH, NiAlZr-LDH and NiAlCe-LDH, respectively, showing that the a parameter tends to increase as the aluminum is substituted by cations with a larger ionic radius such as cerium and zirconium cations. Fig. S1 shows the infrared spectra of precursor materials. The bands at ca. 1550 and 1380 cm−1, are related, respectively, to the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration modes of the carboxylate group in the terephthalate anion [40], being more intense for the NiAlCe-LDH material. The broad absorption band in the region 3000–3600 cm−1 refers to the OH stretching vibrations, ν(OH) correspondent with hydroxyl groups in the layers and interlayer water. At 1700 cm−1 the band of angular deformation δ(H–O–H) in interlayer water molecules was observed. The bands close to 1020 cm−1 can be assigned to Al–O stretching vibrations in octahedral AlO6 units [41]. Thermogravimetric curves of the precursor materials and derivative mass loss curves are displayed in Fig. S2. All materials presented a similar tendency in their thermal evolution and three typical mass loss ranges were identified, in agreement with [42]: dehydration from 30 to 200 °C, dehydroxylation between 200 and 370 °C and terephthalate combustion at 370–600 °C. Above this temperature, the materials reach thermal equilibrium and no further mass loss was observed. For this reason, 600 °C was the chosen calcination temperature retained for catalyst synthesis. The total mass losses were 56.2%, 45.5% and 43.4 % for NiAl-LDH, NiAlCe-LDH and NiAlZr-LDH, respectively. It is important to note that the NiAlCe-LDH material presented an additional mass loss simultaneous with the dehydroxylation (DTG curve showed the peculiarities of this sample more clearly). This step, between 200 and 370 °C, could be related to the decomposition of the cerium segregated phase observed in the XRD diffractogram (see Fig. 1). Fig. 2 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the mixed oxides obtained from the calcination of the LDHs precursors. Poorly crystallized phases were observed. In the case of NiAl, a mixture of nickel oxide NiO (ICSD collection code 87108) with possible NiAl2O4 nickel aluminate spinel phase (ICSD collection code 72067) or poorly structured transition alumina were observed. In the case of NiAlZr, tetragonal ZrO2 (ICSD collection code 68589) was suggested together with NiO. In the NiAlCe material, ceria CeO2 (ICSD collection code 88752) was well characterized, together with traces of NiO. A definite crystallization of Al2O3 was never observed, indicating that either the Al (III) ions inserted into the NiO network, forming a solid solution, or the potential aluminum oxide phase is quite amorphous. The textural properties of mixed oxides were evaluated by N2 sorption experiments. Specific surface areas, calculated by the BET method, BJH-desorption pore volume and pore average diameter are shown in Table 2 . The adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution are displayed in Fig. 3 . All materials showed type IV isotherms according to the IUPAC classification, indicating that the materials are mesoporous [43]. According to the same classification, the hysteresis loops for NiAlCe and NiAlZr are of H3 type, characteristic of materials containing macropores not filled by nitrogen condensate; while NiAl oxide has an H2(a) hysteresis loop, suggesting the presence of well-ordered mesopores. These observations are confirmed through the pore size distribution graph (Fig. 3) where the NiAl presented a narrow and unimodal pore size distribution curve in the mesoporous range with a maximum close to 38 Å whereas NiAlCe and NiAlZr showed the presence of mesopores and large meso/macropores through a bimodal pore size distribution. The NiAl oxide has a higher surface area than NiAlCe and NiAlZr catalysts. Thus, with the cerium and zirconium addition there was a decrease in the surface area, probably associated with the formation of some CeO2 and ZrO2 segregated phases, which are less-porous materials and may promote substantial blocking of pores in the catalyst surface [44]. However, the surface area of NiAlZr area was not as small as that of NiAlCe. Such a fact is attributed to the presence of the tetragonal zirconia phase, as identified by XRD results. This tetragonal phase has a higher specific surface area than monoclinic zirconia. [45]. Thermogravimetric desorption of pyridine previously adsorbed on NiAl, NiAlZr and NiAlCe materials (Fig. S3) showed two principal mass losses. The first, in the range from 30 to 280 °C, may be related to the desorption of pyridine chemisorbed at Lewis acid sites present in alumina and NiO. Due to pyridine desorption in a low-temperature range, the corresponding acid sites are considered to show weak to medium strength. The second mass loss is observed in the range from 280 to 620 °C and is probably related to the desorption of chemically adsorbed pyridine in Bronsted strong acidic sites. Table 2 shows the quantification of acid sites in the two temperature ranges, based on the assumption that a single pyridine molecule is adsorbed on a single acid site. Values in Table 2 show that the order of decreasing acidity is NiAl>NiAlZr>NiAlCe. The acidity of NiAl can be assigned to Lewis acid sites from Ni2+ and Al3+ oxides and Brønsted acid sites associated with bridging OH groups on the catalyst surface [26]. The NiAlZr and NiAlCe catalysts presented the lowest weak and medium acidity, given the low aluminum content in these materials (Table 1), mainly responsible for the weak Lewis acidity in NiAl oxide. In addition, strong acidity sites also decreased with the inclusion of promoters such as cerium and zirconium, diminishing the strong interaction between nickel and aluminum that is responsible for the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel phase [31]. In fact, this spinel phase was not detected by the XRD diffractograms in the NiAlCe and NiAlZr catalysts. 3.2 Thermal and thermo-catalytic pyrolysis of oily waste Following the AOCS Ca 5a-40 official titration method [33], the FFA quantity found in the OW sample was 37.5%, confirming high residual acidity. FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. S4) enabled identification of the main functional groups present in the oily residue, either pure or after adsorption on the oxide catalysts. The band at 3010 cm−1 is assigned to C-H axial deformation in the olefinic double bonds and is less evident for OW/catalysts. The bands in the 1400–1200 cm−1 region, 2930 and 2842 cm−1 are attributed to aliphatic CH2 and CH3 groups present in FFA and triglycerides. The band at 1285 cm−1 corresponds to the C-O stretch. The bands close to 1750 cm−1 correspond to C-O in ester. Thus, the presence of these peaks is clearly related to triglycerides and derived products [46,47]. The intense band at 1710 cm−1 for OW is attributed to stretching of the asymmetric -C=O carbonyl groups [48]. This band, strongly related to FFA presence, was not detected in all OW/catalysts. This indicates the strong interaction between the oily waste and the surface sites of the catalysts induced by the adsorption process used in the present study, mainly through the carboxylic group of the FFA. The pyrograms of oily waste pure and adsorbed on catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The pyrogram of pure OW was much simpler than that obtained after pyrolysis of OW/oxides: the increment in the peaks quantity and their relative intensities is evidence of the positive effect of the catalysts on the transformation of oily waste in many products. Close to 115 compounds were identified. In all pyrograms, a series of homologous peaks was identified (dotted gray lines in Fig. 4), corresponding to 1-alkenes from 1-pentene (1-C5) to 1-heptadecene (1-C17) suggesting that decarboxylation, decarbonylation (de-COx reactions) and cracking have an important role in the pyrolysis mechanisms improved by the presence of NiAl-M catalysts. The 1-C17 was the alkene with the highest carbon number chain obtained: this alkene is generally found in important quantities during the decarboxylation of C18 stearic acid [22,48]. In the catalytic pyrolysis process, the formation of aromatics was observed (dotted red lines in Fig. 4) with toluene, benzene and ethyl-benzene as the most representative compounds. An alkyl-benzene homolog series was identified, from C1 (Toluene) up to C12 (dodecyl-benzene), the alkyl chain being of linear type. These observations agree with previous results reported for the pyrolysis of myristic acid adsorbed on NiAl oxides also issued from LDH precursors [26]. Fig. 5 shows the biplot graph (score + loading) of the principal component analysis (PCA) that presents the correlation between the catalyst types and the main product families obtained from pyrolysis of OW residues. Principal components 1 and 2 together explain 94% variance of the data. PC1 is directly linked to the nature of pyrolysis: catalytic or non-catalytic; PC2 is related to selectivity to oxygenated compounds or hydrocarbons. Thermal pyrolysis differs from catalytic because of the presence of fatty acids and fatty acid esters. Catalytic pyrolysis favored the degradation of the oily residue, transforming it into hydrocarbons and mono-oxygenated products. Among the catalysts, the NiAlCe favored the production of ketones, aldehydes and hydrocarbons, especially polyenes and alkanes. NiAl and NiAlZr catalysts favored the production of aromatic hydrocarbons, alkenes and alcohols. The PCA correlations between the main products individually and the catalyst type from the pyrolysis of OW residue are shown in Fig. 6 . The principal components 1 and 2 together explain the variance of 88% of the data. PC2 is related to the degree of deoxygenation. It is observed that the pyrolysis of the pure OW residue differs from the catalytic pyrolysis mainly by the formation of the compound 14-methyl-8-Hexadecenal. NiAl and NiAlZr catalysts, the most acidic, favored the production of light hydrocarbons such as propene, 2-Butene and aromatics such as benzene and toluene. In contrast, NiAlCe favored the production of ketones especially undecanone, dodecanone, tridecanone, and also some hydrocarbons. Thermal and catalytic pyrolysis are similar in terms of obtaining alkenes and 10-Pentadecene-1-ol and 1-hexadecanol, alcohol products that are grouped in the center of the biplot graph. Fig. 7 displays the results of product yields, estimated from the values of the areas of the peaks, from the fast pyrolysis of OW and OW/catalysts. The compounds were grouped into four main categories: CO2, hydrocarbons, oxygenated compounds and unidentified products. The CO2 yield increased with catalyst use, especially with the NiAlCe, indicating the occurrence of decarboxylation reactions. The number of unidentified products increased due to greater conversion and therefore greater presence of compounds derived from consecutive cracking reactions in presence of the catalysts. The yield of oxygenated compounds was lower in the OW/NiAl catalyst mixture pyrolysis. The deoxygenation efficiency can be linked to the strong adsorption of the oily waste on the catalyst surface, favored by both the higher Ni content and the higher specific surface area of this particular catalyst [24,26]. NiAlZr and NiAlCe catalysts showed a higher yield of oxygenated compounds, mainly due to the presence of ketones, aldehydes and alcohols, possibly associated to the presence of oxygen vacancies introduced by the oxides ZrO2 and CeO2 [28,31]. The main information arising from Fig. 7 is the increase in hydrocarbon formation, i.e. the better deoxygenation of the feed when catalysts are used. A second observation can be made when looking at Fig. 7: with the exception of CO2, where quantification variation may reach some 20% in a duplicate run, the relative standard deviation in the quantity of oxygenated and deoxygenated compounds is always smaller than 5%, indicating that the present experimental conditions are well controlled. Fig. 8 details the distribution of hydrocarbon families from the fast pyrolysis of OW, classified as alkanes, alkenes, polyenes and aromatics. In the presence of mixed oxide catalysts, the production of aromatics and monoalkenes was clearly increased, whereas the polyenes and saturated products increased less, compared to pyrolysis without a catalyst. The NiAl catalyst was the material with the highest selectivity to aromatics, especially toluene, benzene, ethyl-benzene, pentyl-benzene and styrene. The high production of aromatics, in this case, can be correlated to the higher acidity of the NiAl catalyst. NiAl is therefore not only responsible for the cracking of the molecules, but also for hydrogen transfer reactions associated with aromatization [49,50]. The NiAl catalyst also produced polycyclic aromatics, such as methyl-naphthalene, which are precursors of coke formation [51]. These polyaromatics were not observed with NiAlCe and NiAlZr, showing that the introduction of zirconium and cerium can inhibit catalyst deactivation by coke production. This result agrees with previous data reported in the literature about the pyrolysis of fatty compounds using Ni, Ce, Zr supported catalysts [31,32]. More alkenes were produced when using the NiAlZr catalyst. Among these, propene, 2-butene, and 1-alkenes such as 1-pentene, 1-hexene, 1-pentadecene, 1-heptene and 1-nonene were the products presenting the higher yields. In the case of OW/NiAlCe pyrolysis, the production of polyenes and alkanes was superior compared to the other cases. Patil and Vaidya [52] observed that CeO2 acts as a weak Lewis base and tends to donate electrons to a metal, improving its reduction capacity. In the present case, the catalyst NiAlCe could promote the cracking of unsaturated hydrocarbons, producing polyunsaturated compounds and alkanes. Also, the improvement of the hydrogenating capacity of Ni in the presence of Ce promoted the formation of alkanes [31]. Another important result was the production of linear alkylbenzenes homolog series (from octyl- to dodecyl-benzene) in similar amounts in all catalysts. Long-chain linear alkylbenzenes are value-added petrochemical feedstocks for the production of biodegradable surfactants. Classification of the obtained hydrocarbons through the number of carbon chain ranges is shown in Fig. 9 . The light hydrocarbons range (C3-C4) was favored by the Zr-containing catalyst, whereas the C5-C9 hydrocarbons range (gasoline) was promoted in the presence of NiAl catalyst. The three catalysts showed the same C10-C13 hydrocarbon range (kerosene-type fuel) and a non-negligible amount of alkyl-benzenes C14+. Higher amounts of C14+ hydrocarbons range, compatible with diesel-like fuels, were observed with both NiAlCe and NiAlZr, implying an inhibition of secondary cracking reactions during pyrolysis, the result of a decrease in acidity strength of these catalysts compared with NiAl. Studying the pyrolysis of palmitic acid adsorbed on pure alumina, Santos et al. [22] also observed a preferential formation of C5–C9 hydrocarbons, suggesting that Al-Lewis sites favored hydrocarbons in the gasoline range. Jeon et al. [53] observed that in Ni-CeZrO2, the catalyst with higher acidity enhanced the selectivity toward light hydrocarbons. Fig. 10 displays the oxygenated compound yields for the fast cracking of OW, separated into the main groups: alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids and fatty acid esters. Linoleic acid (carboxylic acid) was only detected in the non-catalytic cracking. The content of fatty acid esters such as dodecanoic acid methyl ester and decanoic acid 2-propenyl ester was reduced considerably for pyrolysis in the presence of catalysts, indicating a better conversion of the raw material by both the high temperature of cracking and the catalytic effect of the materials. Ketones such as undecanone, dodecanone, tridecanone and 4-cyclohexyl-2-butanone were identified with the NiAlCe catalyst; their volume was greater with NiAlCe than with NiAlZr (dotted blue lines in Fig. 4). Phung et al. [54] observed that the pyrolysis of vegetable oil over a catalyst with basic properties derived from HDL favored the production of ketones. Aldehydes such as dodecanal, tridecanal, tetradecanal, tetradecenal, pentadecenal and hexadecanal were produced in significant amounts when using NiAlCe and in lower amounts when the pyrolysis occurred with NiAlZr. Dodecanol, tridecanol, tetradecanol, tetradecenol, pentadecenol and hexadecanol were the main alcohols found as pyrolysis products, in the case of OW pyrolysis in presence of NiAlCe. The formation of alcohols as intermediates may come from a hydrogenation pathway of carboxylic acids [31]. In this case, hydrogen may be produced from dehydrocyclization and aromatization reactions in the presence of aluminum-containing catalysts [49]. It is striking that C12 to C16 alcohols, C12 to C16 aldehydes, C11 to C13 ketones, have many similarities in terms of chain length and structure and are always produced in better amounts when using NiAlCe than with the other catalysts. Such a fact suggests that aldehydes and alcohols have a common mechanism of formation and that an oxy-reductor solid promotor such as Ce(IV) and to a lower extent Zr(IV) participate directly in the initial decomposition mechanism of OW, but limiting further transformation of these oxygenated species. It can be recalled that alcohols and ketones, together with oxygenated products of thermal pyrolysis such as carboxylic acids and fatty acid esters can be further deoxygenated, for example, by recycling a fraction of the products into the pyrolysis reactor, in order to increase the global deoxygenation degree of the OW residue. 4 Conclusions Layered double hydroxides of NiAl, NiAlZr and NiAlCe were successively prepared as precursors of unsupported bulk mixed oxide catalysts with high specific surface area. Fast pyrolysis at 600 °C of oily waste (OW) from the vegetable oil industry, containing triglycerides and a high amount of free fatty acids was performed, producing mainly 1-alkenes, lower carbon chain fatty acids, and fatty acid esters. Pyrolysis in the presence of NiAl-M catalysts produced 1-alkenes from C3 to C17 and linear alkylbenzenes that are petrochemical precursors of biodegradable surfactants production. The NiAlCe catalyst favored the production of polyenes and alkanes as hydrocarbons and ketones as oxygenates. The NiAl and NiAlZr catalysts favored the production of aromatics and alkenes. NiAlZr was selective to alcohols and ketones in a smaller amount than NiAlCe. These results show that the use of an unsupported mixed oxide catalyst, combining Ni as hydrogenating metal with Al2O3 as acid material can modulate the production of specific hydrocarbon product families. The addition of Ce and Zr to NiAl reduced acidity and produce fewer polyaromatics that are precursors of coke. These materials proved to be useful for the conversion of vegetable oil residues to produce precursors of hydrocarbons for second-generation drop-in biofuels and bio-based surfactants, contributing to the decarbonization of industry without competing with food crops. coredata.dc:description: High acidic vegetable oil feedstocks and wastes are not suitable for conventional biodiesel production. These wastes could be used to produce cheap hydrocarbon-rich biofuels without affecting food production. In this work, we studied the hydrogen-free fast pyrolysis and deoxygenation of an acidic industrial vegetable oil waste for biofuels and chemicals production, assessing the effect of Ce or Zr on NiAl mixed oxides obtained from layered double hydroxides. Oily waste (OW) was pre-adsorbed on the catalysts using a Catalyst:OW mass ratio of 5:1. Without a catalyst, pyrolysis of OW, containing triglycerides and a high percentage of free fatty acids, produced mainly 1-alkenes, lower carbon chain fatty acids, and fatty acid esters. Catalytic pyrolysis increased hydrocarbons favoring 1-alkenes between propene and 1-heptadecene, as well as alkyl-benzenes. Linear alkylbenzenes are feedstock for the production of biodegradable surfactants. NiAlCe was most selective to polyenes, alkanes and ketones, while NiAl and NiAlZr catalysts were efficient in producing aromatics, alkenes and light hydrocarbons in the GLP and gasoline range (C3-C10). The combination of acidic and metallic properties on high surface area unsupported bulk mixed oxide catalysts can be used to maximize the production of specific-range hydrocarbons for second-generation drop-in biofuels and bio-based surfactant precursors, towards the decarbonization of industry.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogen-free deoxygenation of industrial vegetable oil waste using Ce, Zr-NiAl catalysts for second-generation biofuels production
